Chances are that if you attend an elite school, your parents probably have a similar educational background. Your friends probably hail from a similar background, and their parents probably come from a similar background as your parents, and so on. Basically, upon leaving this school you're not much in a different place from where you started. For people like first-generation college students and the children of immigrants, to attend such a university would mean to open multiple doors of opportunity. Historically, education has played a crucial role in social mobility and the situation is no different today. People often envision ascending the socioeconomic ladder as a linear path - hard work and perseverance will surely pay off?! - but the American Dream is not as one-dimensional as seems. Even if the combination of the pedigree of your degree and your toil lands you a desirable, high-paying job, that alone won't secure your future. Remember the Princeton Mom who warned educated, ambitious women to snag their husband in college? She makes sweeping generalizations that are unfair to both men and women, but I personally can't help but feel that there is a grain of legitimacy to her ramblings. These elite universities provide a unique opportunity for people from all walks of life to mingle and form meaningful relationships with each other. They provide not only academic and professional opportunities, but social opportunities as well. Who knows? You might end up marrying someone from a "higher" socioeconomic background, thus further cementing your new position on the jungle gym that is the social ladder. Your children might enjoy the things that your parents were never able to give you. You won't face the same pressures and worries that your parents faced when they raised you.  Once, my friend and I laughed over what we would've ended up as if our parents had stayed in their home countries. He said something about being a corn picker; I don't know my fate but it likely wouldn't include plans of studying science.

It matters if you make the most of it. However, the resources offered at Harvard or Princeton are not going to just magically make you better off. And people in the professional world are not going to be “wowed” because you went to Cornell or Columbia - these people either attended them, knew people who attended them, dropped out of them, etc… Point being, people in the professional world understand what these institutions are really like, and how these institutions don’t always accept the most promising students, nor do the most promising students always attend them. The brand name of your alma mater doesn’t take you as far as you think it would. However, Harvard and other Ivy League universities, as well as their peers - Williams, Duke, Northwestern, UChicago, MIT/Caltech/Harvey Mudd, Pomona, Stanford - benefit in being highly resource rich. There are tons of more easily accessible resources from being an undergraduate at these institutions compared to larger public universities or places like USC. That being said, you don’t get an education by osmosis (it’s shocking how many people think some semblance of this idea) - you have to work at it. You have to be involved, to prove yourself to your professors, to gun for research / internships, to network within the college’s alumni and abroad etc. Just because your peers at Harvard all have high scores and have accomplished significantly in high school will mean very little in terms of your future success, except that you have to work even harder to distinguish yourself in using the resources that Harvard offers. If you stagnate after acceptance to the illustrious Ivy League, you will find that the Ivy League diploma, or any prestigious institution’s diploma, will not help you in the slightest other than for impressing people at debutante balls.

Yes, at least sometimes. In my case, in two ways: I got my Masters and was working on my PhD. at a small state university - a good school, with high student/faculty involvement, and good faculty. However, I was bored and somewhat floundering, because my advisor had recently left, and everyone in my department had joked that he and I were pretty much the only two who understood each other, since we were in a less common sub-specialty. The response was that if he ever left, I’d have to go work with HIS advisor. Well he was from an Ivy, and his advisor was still there. Some months after he left, he called and said he was visiting his advisor, who was interested in meeting me and possibly having me apply and working with him. Dream come true, academically! Not personally, since I was happily married, my spouse was under contract at the small state university, we owned a house, etc. But as I tossed out this idea around my department, one professor said “It’s an Ivy. You’d be an idiot if you didn’t give it a chance.” I went out there right away, applied, got accepted, and transferred. My spouse moved to join me in a year, we sold our house and got another, and I’ve never regretted it for a moment. There were so many more opportunities academically, not just in that department, but other departments with courses related to my interests. So First: having a variety of perhaps more esoteric and advanced course offerings available, was a clear advantage of the Ivy vs the small state university. Second, more faculty were involved in funded research projects at the Ivy than the small state University. That meant more opportunities to get hands-on with research, to make presentations, to get published, and to get funding. I worked with at least one other professor, but I wasn’t really interested in his research and decided to do my own thing instead. But this wasn’t an option at the original school, where a small minority of the faculty had research projects for grad students to work on. (On the other hand, at the smaller school the faculty didn’t seem to have the pressure that they did at the Ivy, so there was more time for and possibly more interest in the students.) Third, a number of years later, when I was finishing/finished with my doctorate and applying and interviewing for faculty positions, at least 3–4 times, the faculty or administrators interviewing me specifically mentioned my “Ivy Degree” as a plus. Having a degree from an Ivy did make a difference in terms of job offers, at least for faculty positions. I’ve always been in academia, so outside of academia, I don’t know - but the Ivy degree gave me an edge in my academic job search.

The answer to this question depends on what you believe matters? How do you define success? If your goal is to get a competitive job at a competitive firm and nothing else then it may very well matter. Some places are innately biased towards specific Universities and Ivy League education. If success to you is more broad and can take many avenues and you would accept working anywhere for the job you want then it does not matter. What I tell people is that reaching our goal is like walking a 100 step stair case. Some people are born with the means to be on step 80 and others at step 1. We move up and down those steps depending on life circumstances but the goal is always obtainable it just takes some more time then others. Sometimes you start so far back with so many obstacles that knock you back a step that you do not have enough time in your lifespan to reach the top. That does not make our goal any less attainable. An Ivy League education is just a booster to get you toward the top but does not determine your ability to get there as long as your goal isn’t too overly specific. Perseverance (NOT persistence, there is a subtle difference if you look it up) and at times persistence is what I believe matter most in life in obtaining your goals. We are always fighting against demotivating factors in our life. If you stay lower on the stair case you might have to have more perseverance and persistence then others. If someone places too much value on things like Ivy League education then they may also be from the camp who either their parents and/or themselves believe failure is not an option. The most successful people recognize that failure is a part of life and progress. The debate for and against failure is not an option is extremely important because our current push in education is to instill an urgency for perfection. That is a toxic mentality because nothing and no one is perfect. If you look at it from a sales perspective (we are all salesmen, even students are trying to sell that they know things to teachers and teachers are trying to sell knowledge) which is more realistic? “Failure is not an option” or as Michael Jordan said “I’ve failed over and over and over in life and that is why I succeed.” Well if you look at what character trait each statement is pushing it becomes evident. From a sales perspective the only way that failure is not an option (meaning all sales pitches are a success) is to be perfectly persuasive. No amount of persistence would close all sales. No one is perfectly persuasive. Bias, skepticism, and beliefs will drive many to never buy certain things. On the other quote what MJ was expressing was perseverance and persistence are the necessary traits for success. We need to stop pushing perfection and push perseverance and persistence.

I have read many answers about this on Quora, either via my Digest or in my feed, that go on for pages about how ‘prestige doesn’t matter’ and how students should ‘focus on schools which fit them best’, and if I’m being honest, I’m sick to my stomach. The mentality of settling for less and rationalising it as a better decision because of inconsequential and ultimately irrelevant factors is something I saw a lot of, growing up. In elementary school, we had a class ranking system, and man, in my first year, my classmates were competitive. Back then, class ranks were determined by 1, sometimes 2 marks, as it was absurdly easy to score full marks in every test. Striving for perfection, for that one extra mark to gain an edge over everyone else, was what we all aspired to. As the years went by, and the tests became progressively harder, students who maintained better grades were streamed into elite classes with higher course loads, which those who couldn’t stayed in normal classes. In my last year of elementary school, I distinctly remember hearing a student from a normal class remarking that there was no point in getting into an elite class anyway because all it meant was that they had lesser time to play in the afternoons, plus the teachers were a lot harder on you because they expected more, so really what was there to gain? These attitudes worsened as I entered middle school and high school. The excuses changed from having lesser time for video games to having parents with lower expectations so you wouldn’t have to be lectured every time you flunked a test, but at the core they were still excuses. When all was said and done, and it was time to apply for university, these students found themselves in a bind, as their track records of Bs and Cs automatically eliminated them from contention for admissions into any remotely competitive university. So what did they say then? ‘It’s fine. Going to a local university, even if it means an inferior standard of education, is better because it’s less of a financial burden for my parents, and education is the same wherever you go anyway. Besides, I’d get homesick if I ever left the country.” The most frustrating thing about people like these is that they don’t understand that they hamstring themselves every time they rationalise their lack of drive. I feel like this question is a prime example of that. Saying that an Ivy League education doesn’t matter is in no way representative of reality, and is instead a reflection of the expectations you set for yourself.  There are two broadly different views towards education in my experience. The Western view, which is that education is the procurement of skills you need in life and the single most important thing about education is discovering who you are, and the Asian view, which is that education is one of the only tools for upwards social mobility that poor/middle class citizens can take advantage of on a level playing field. The Western view stems not only from the desire to see individuals have a holistic education, but also to enable children to live fulfilled lives. That’s great, because going forward, as the world’s population becomes increasingly literate and standards of living improve, that’s what we should be aiming for. But right now, for the vast majority of the developing world, the same rules don’t apply, and many of the people who write answers to questions like these don’t realise that.  ‘B-but you can go to a decent, but not quite elite school, or to your local state university, and still do just as well in life!’ I hear you protest. And… yeah. You’re right. You’ll do just fine. Work at a medium-sized company if you’re lucky, score an easy 9 to 5 job, fall in love, get married, have kids, and retire at 60 with some money in the bank. Live out a life of relative mediocrity, eventually dying peacefully in your sleep. Except that isn’t how it is for the rest of us.  Nearly 700 million people live on less than $1.90 a day. One in nine people go to bed with no food in their stomach. In many countries around the world, GDP per capita is much lower than the American average of $65,118.40 a year. Some countries have GDP per capitas of less than a thousand dollars a year. Many of these people would give an arm, a leg and then some to attend an Ivy League, and gain access to the opportunities that so many people on Quora seem to take for granted. Those who say getting an Ivy League education doesn’t matter remind of cappuccino communists. It’s easy to say what they say because they don’t live in that reality.  To be able to question whether an Ivy League education matters is absurd. Because it undoubtedly does. It’s not about ‘which school is the best fit for me’ when the only other option is never lifting yourself out of poverty. It’s about aiming high, working your butt off and achieving your goals, or at the very least getting most of the way there. Your freedom of choice was taken from you the moment you told yourself you were going to get into a top school no matter what. There’s no such thing as consolation prizes when it comes to things like this. Either you win, or you lose. What’s important, though, isn’t winning or losing: it’s what you tell yourself. If you tell yourself that going to an Ivy League doesn’t matter because you know you’ll never make it there — well, that’s half the battle you’ve already lost.

Does attending an Ivy League school really matter? That’s a great question. I strongly believe the greatest value that comes from attending a top university has to do more with the signaling effect of that institution. For example, attending a Stanford or Harvard will open up more opportunities that you can possibly imagine. The name brand of the institution is where the value of the degree lies. With that being said, there isn’t anything special about the curriculum or education that you get at these schools. If you’re learning calculus or computer science, you’ll still be taking the same courses such as operating systems, data structures, and what not. In fact, you can find MIT’s entire set of courses at MIT courseware, so what’s the point of attending MIT? It’s the name brand of the degree. It’s almost like saying that you don’t need a Rolex to tell time. But people will still try to go and buy that Rolex. Or a Mercedes to take you from point A to point B. Any car will do, but people will still aspire for that luxury car. Other than the brand name of the school, at an Ivy League you will be surrounded with an intellectually vibrant community of peers and faculty. There is real value in that, as well. You might even get taught be a prestigious professor who pioneered that field. So is an Ivy League degree worth it? I’ll leave that up for you to decide. But I can tell you it certainly is in very high demand, and in economics we coin it as a luxury good. With the advent of online education, you can get a superb mode of learning on the Internet - even better than that of an Ivy League. You can also get access to quite a comprehensive Ivy League curriculum through Coursera. But just like how any watch can tell time, or any car can take you from A to B, people still want the best - because it is a signal of prestige and ability more so than what it actually has to offer. And that is why people aspire to attend the Ivy League.

With the exception to the financially challenged who don't understand the aid options provided by Ivies (plus MIT, Stanford, CalTech, etc), those holistically and intellectually gifted thus able to attend an Ivy who choose a State school for anything other than top tier athletics seem to be leaving something on the table. It is hard to imagine why someone of a high driven and top performing calibur would choose otherwise. Of course there are those who aspire to run the family business, teach locally, deeply family/friend rooted, or perhaps don't require the lifetime credibility and top peer support provided by an Ivy League education. But typically those who ARE academically and socially accomplished toward the top 1% (Ivy type person) are NOT the same people who will accept status quo at an otherwise good or even excellent state school. These students have accomplished at the highest levels and are driven to the highest levels…which are exactly the students sought by Ivy-type institutions (incl Stanford, MIT, CTech, etc). To use a sports analogy, a world-class athlete will not settle for regional competions. The top football players in the world will not settle for a start-up league…or a local league. So how would academics possibly be different for the top driven academic/social minds? Sure…comments here are that the world is filled with some of the brightest minds at non-Ivy universities — undisputed. But clearly the percentage of bright minds and the challenge to maximize efforts among peers exists moreso at a top 20 World University than at a top 100. Saying otherwise would mean the admissions groups at these top 20 universities (Ivy+) fail in their selectivity AND that the demand of the world's top students to attend these distinguished universitites is greatly overstated. Quality in typically leads to quality out. And most understand this concept.

I think it is widely thought that going to an ivy league school makes a big difference because one can network with other elite people in a way that will lead to future success. I think just about everyone has believed this (including me). But a recent major study casts serious doubt on this conclusion. This study followed a very interesting group of students. These students applied to and were accepted at Ivy League -level sorts of schools. But for various reasons, usually financial (the cost), they ended up choosing to go to lower-level schools, like Penn State. The study compared the later life success of these students to the later life success of students who actually did go to Ivy League schools. The result, which surprised just about everyone, was that the non-ivy-attending students were as successful in their future lives as the ivy-attending students (!). How can we explain this result, assuming that future work replicates it? The most reasonable and simplest guess is that having the intelligence, talent and diligence that leads to getting into an ivy league school is what is more important, not the networking at the school. People who have this kind of talent will find ways to end up equally successful whether or not they go to ivy league schools and meet other ivy league people. So there is a good chance that the networking benefits of going to ivy league schools have been much overestimated. While there are other possible explanations, this seems like the most straightforward one. So if the result holds up, it appears that the networking effects of going to Ivy League schools, at least at the undergraduate level (the study didn’t look at graduate students) have been oversold, a very striking and possibly important result. There may be of course other benefits to going to such schools, but since the networking benefit is the one everyone cites, it is very striking to see that there is currently no empirical support for it.

Of course not, the school itself is just a placeholder for something that is difficult to attain. It’s not like the kids at Harvard, Stanford, or Yale are somehow getting a crazy amount more than kids from a state school. The curriculums are probably more involved, yes, but that’s not because of the school. It’s because the kids who get into those schools are usually standard deviations smarter than whatever the median is. The median SAT score accepted into Harvard is 1520. That means 50 percent of kids getting in have a higher score than that. The 75th percentile is 1580. That’s absolutely insane. To put that into context:  The 50th percentile of acceptance into Harvard translates to the 99th percentile for the SAT. So while the ivy league schools themselves don’t matter, the kids that get admitted are already insanely gifted and smart before they ever step foot onto the campus. There was a kid I met in my third semester at U.C. Berkeley. He was a legitimate genius. In our upper-division combinatorics class, he would correct the professor’s mistakes on the chalkboard every 5 minutes or so. There were only 15 of us in the class, and I actually think he knew the entire course better than the person teaching us. He could conceptualize things and compartmentalize mathematics in a way I didn’t know was possible. It was beauty and elegance. No, Berkeley didn’t teach him those things. But it made sense that he was at an elite campus learning mathematics. I likely wouldn’t find him at a state school. In all my years before Berkeley or after, I have never met a kid like that. Harvard didn’t produce the highest number of U.S. presidents. It’s just that all the potential presidents ended up going to Harvard. The best generally gravitate toward the best.

What really matters is attendance at a school where the other students are smart, hard working, and motivated. That tends to be the case at Ivy League schools, which is why their reputation is so high. If you do well in such a challenging school, then you are very likely to do well at your job, regardless of what it turns out to be. So what I recommend is that you look at the reputation of any school you are considering. You can probably get a good sense from your counselor, but if in doubt, talk to some businessman who hires people. Many schools are excellent. When I chaired the admissions committee for the physics graduate program at UC Berkeley, I jumped at the opportunity to hire someone from any of the Claremont Colleges (e.g. Harvey Mudd) for example. There are many schools with similar reputations, from Swarthmore, to Reed, to Stanford, to Notre Dame. Note that I do not include my own school, UC Berkeley in this list. At UC Berkeley you can get an education as good as at any Ivy League School, and better than at about half of them. However, it is possible to get a degree from UC Berkeley without getting a first class education, and employers know that. So if you go to UC Berkeley, future employers will give you more scrutiny than if you go elsewhere. You can graduate from anywhere and get a good education and a good job. There is an advantage in graduating from a college with a great reputation. All the Ivy League schools have that—but so do many others.

It ultimately depends on what you want to do. There are two other lawyers in my family, my sister who attended an Ivy League Law school and the my cousin who attended a very elite law school in the south. But ironically, neither of them actually wanted to have a high power job. My sister wanted to do public interest work and help families in need of legal aid, and my cousin entered law school in hopes of being a prosecutor. In terms of legal careers, these are very ordinary. So they could have achieved what they set out to accomplish without going to an Ivy League school. My sister and cousin ended up taking out loans to attend these schools, but these aren’t exactly high paying jobs. My cousin instead of becoming a prosecutor went into a BigLaw firm so he could pay off his student loans, he plans to leave as soon as he makes his last payment. My sister still hasn’t finished paying off her loans, as she doesn’t make much money working with impoverished clients, but she loves the work she does. I chose not to go to an Ivy League and instead went to a lower ranked school on a full scholarship precisely because I didn’t know what I wanted to practice, so I thought it’d be best to avoid taking out the same loans. What Ivy League and elite universities are very great at doing is getting graduates through the doors in very high places. So for Law, it’s very difficult to get a BigLaw firm position if you don’t attend a top 14 (T14) school. Even if you go to a top 50 Law school like I did, you’ll need to be at the top of your class, be on a Journal, Moot Court, etc… whereas Harvard and Yale grads will be given preference even if they didn’t do that simply because they went to a Harvard and Yale. Currently, all of the Supreme Court Justices attended an Ivy League school. As a consequence, getting a clerkship under a SCOTUS Justice after law school is very prestigious and those spots almost always go to Harvard and Yale graduates. Even an ordinary clerkship for a federal trial judge is coveted and difficult to obtain, if you don’t go to an elite law school. But this doesn’t just apply to Law, but to banking and finance for elite Wall Street firms and big tech companies as well. It’s very difficult to get into a place like Goldman Sachs if you didn’t study at Princeton or Wharton. Companies like Google and Apple have a very disproportionately large number of Stanford and MIT. But if you just want to work at a regular place or institution like as a school teacher or nurse and you don’t care where, then you don’t need to go to an Ivy League. But I’m sure Ivy League credentials would help if you land the job though.

The Ivy League is merely a northeastern sports league. Several colleges decided to not spend on scholarships to encourage amateur athletics. I do not know the full details. They happened to be some of the oldest private colleges in our nation. But in common practice, we term other schools “comps.” Such colleges or universities are MIT, Cal Tech, Univ. of Chicago, Stanford, Amherst, Georgetown. Swarthmore, Smith, Bryn Mawr, Wellesley. Other great schools often noted are Rutgers, Univ. of Michigan, Univ. of Wisconsin, and places such as Oberlin. It is not the Ivy League or idiocy. Hardly, every state university has outstanding students. I know some comps are omitted from my list. In practice, any of such grads are invited or admitted to gatherings and are welcome. There are a few exceptions. The Ivies have geographical and even subject limitations. Every region has excellent universities. But I did not know when I applied to college. The Princeton Club, for instance, in Manhattan accepts so many from top colleges that are not Ivies. I would say the main driver from Ivy League alums is that we seek those who are very bright, do extensive reading, and have life passions. A few are snarky and mean to others. But it is a very small portion. Most are eager to expand our contacts as long as we do not have people who just do not care much about education. This country is blessed with great educational institutions. Our elite schools in all regions do amazing jobs of imparting knowledge and building character. Yes, some nerds are snarky. This country would be hard-pressed if only the Ivies were excellent. Oh, Univ. of Texas should also be on my list. Depending on location. There are downsides to the Ivies, too. We tend to think alike. It can close off views and other alternative actions. It is kind of lazy to call excellent colleges Ivies. But this the reality. Every Ivy is superb. But other colleges also rank in the superb category.

Yes. But only in the sense that it’d be the biggest personal/financial/professional mistake of your life. I’m going to steal from a talk I heard this past weekend about not only why an Ivy League degree doesn’t matter, but why no college degrees matter. A degree is a credential. The college/university you attended is a signal of your abilities based on a set of standards that particular school presents. Let’s say you go to Harvard. When you graduate and get your degree, that signifies you are “Harvard material”. When you pay tuition, you’re paying for the right to attach the Harvard name to yourself. It says that you adhere to a certain set of standards and qualities that others identify with the Harvard name. You’re not paying for the classes. Not paying for the knowledge. You’re paying for the credential. That credential is dead. No one cares anymore what college or university you graduated from. It doesn’t signify anything but your ability to sit in class and pass tests. Employers want to see what you can do. In college you only complete assignments for professors. In the real world you have to be able to create value. College degrees don’t signify that you can do that. You have to become your own credential. There are better ways to signal your value and skills than through a degree. The internet allows you to develop a digital paper trail of all your work that employers can look up with a google search. Create a personal website. Publish all of your work. Become a voice in your area of expertise. Those three things will set you apart from the standard college graduate. And guess what, it won’t cost you $200,000. Follow my story at michaelkgaines.com

As a current Harvard student – I am going to answer you honestly. No, it doesn’t freaking matter if you attend an Ivy League school or not. Dang, I feel like I am betraying the egos of every Ivy League school by writing that statement. Here’s the truth. Ivy Leagues are wonderful and amazing opportunities. If you are accepted to one, I highly recommend you take the acceptance. However, the will and determination of an individual is what determines success. Ivy Leagues may be an indicator of success – but they do not just make it happen like Tinker Bell with Pixie Dust.  Let me tell you a story: I went to a summer program with a girl whose dream was to go to an elite school – like Yale. She worked her butt off and she really deserved to go to one.  Sadly, it didn’t work out for her. She was rejected from all her top schools. So, she decided to take a year off before going to college. What did she do with that time? Did she just sit and cry? Did she tell herself she would always be a failure? Did she give herself a year-long time-out in the corner of her bedroom? Heck no! Instead, she traveled the world (backpacking on a budget) She learned how to code. And she lived her best life for an entire year.  And guess what? A year later she doesn’t need an Ivy League to be successful, because now she is creating her own app and writes as a travel blogger. The individual determines success, not the school they attended. Who knows? Not going to an Ivy League might be the best thing to ever happen to you. Photo Credit: Disney, Brown University, Hammock Universe

I attended Cornell grad school and have been working in Silicon Valley for the past 10+ years.  Having an Ivy League on the resume has opened a lot of doors for me.  Many of my connections from Cornell also ended up in the valley, in big prestigious companies or thriving promising start-ups.  I didn't necessarily land a particular job directly through my Cornell connections, but the information flow in the network, the amazing people I got to know through extended network kept me updated on interesting opportunities.   Ivy League schools constantly receive generous endowment from its alumni network because alumni see continued benefits they receive by carrying a name of Ivy League throughout their career.  These resources enable the schools to spend on promoting its presence, organizing events for alumni and supporting career development for its students.  It is a strong and healthy circle.   Every once in a while you hear a successful story from the valley that a small start-up makes big - guess what, most, if not all, smart investors look for Ivy League names in a start-up's founder list and/or first few crucial hires before they are willing to bet investment on it. That being said, there are universities on the west coast (Stanford, Berkeley, to name a few) that offer similar, or if you are destined for Silicon Valley, better career development benefits in areas I mentioned above.  A self-driven individual shines regardless.  Putting yourself through a good university helps a lifetime.

The answer can be yes and can be NO as well. Like if you are graduating for a elite college you financial and professional career can be great . According to the economist it really matter to graduate from a ivy league school for a lot of future earning. But primarily it depends on the goals you set for your life .If you want to become a CEO or a president , graduating from the elite college can be benefical for you .Similarly one of the top companies in the world recruit there employee from the elite school only .Also, graduates of elite colleges have an advantage in the business world from strong, powerful alumni networks. However, If you want to be a scientist or teacher, there may not be much of an advantage, at least monetarily, from attending a top school. Again, you can still achieve any professional goal if you attend from normal college , but the graduation rate of Stanford is significantly higher, and the average salaries of Stanford grads are substantially higher. It's important to remember that you can graduate from any college, and if you fully apply yourself, you can be a successful CEO, doctor, engineer, or whatever else you aspire to be. Similarly, if you go to an Ivy League college and try to coast through life without showing the dedication that got you into an elite college, you're likely to experience limited success. World is not the same anymore if you have a skill , enthusiasm and have a courage to do hard work then one can in this world can stop to achieve your goal.

In my opinion it depends. It depends if you are talking about undergrad or grad school. It depends on the field you intend to pursue. It depends on your economic circumstances. It depends on what other opportunities you have available to you (opportunity cost). Etc. etc. In general, I believe academic success is more about the person and their personal desire to learn than the school they attended; career success is more about delivering results and connecting with the right people than graduating for a prestigous university (by the way a large portion of the “important” people to connect with are not Ivy grads). That being said in some fields, and for some certain objectives, an Ivy degree can be a powerful lever to help you on your journey. For example, in law, business, and politics a grad degree from an Ivy could go a long way, but it is not always necessary either. However, in fields like nursing, social work, or medicine an Ivy degree seems like overkill and will not likely impact your results in terms of financial outcomes. In those fields you would generally be better off finding the most efficient/cost effective and accredited path to your career (which probably is not an Ivy). At one time, I was accepted to an Ivy, but it ended up not being a good fit for my future plans. It was super hard to say no to that offer. The Ivy Universities carry prestige, and that prestige makes attending very tempting even when it’s otherwise irrational to do so.

Going to a good school is worth it if you can find one that fits how you work and what you want to do. often, the best schools aren't the Ivies, though. If you're into tech or science, few of the Ivies really are top tier in that many disciplines. In most fields of study, there are alternatives which will leave you just as well connected and probably better educated. if you're doing politics, Yale is great, but so is Georgetown. If you're into music, film or drama, Julliard, NYU or Carnegie Mellon are probably better than any of the Ivies, except maybe for comedy and TV writing. Economics? MIT, U Chicago. Entrepreneurship? Given the choice, you'd be an idiot to go anywhere but Stanford. So no, you're not hosed if you can't get into an Ivy. but it really helps to have a clue what you want to do. because what the Ivies mostly have is quite good breadth, and names and networks that can be quite powerful in every career, where many other schools are only well known within their best areas. A few non-Ivies are of a similar or greater quality, prestige and competitiveness in most areas-- Stanford, Berkeley, etc. That said, none of these places are easy to get into, so best get cracking. Last bit of advice: it really helps to have something you really are into. Doesn't have to be the class president/varsity athlete kind of thing, just something you're legitimately good at and excited about.

Inherently? Nope. While attending an Ivy League school absolutely makes it easier for its students to succeed, it is by no means a requirement. These schools only accept people they believe will go on to reflect well on the school. However, they also reject thousands and thousands of kids with equally as much, if not more, potential every year. If you happen to end up at an Ivy, you probably were likely to succeed wherever you went. An “Ivy League” education is only available to about 0.2% of the US population. If only that 0.2% were capable, intelligent, and ambitious, the nation would crumble. Remember that the Ivy League is just a sports league, not the end all be all of higher education. If you have the drive, you could go to the lowest-ranked school in the country — or drop out of school entirely like Steve Jobs, although I don’t recommend it — and end up very successful. At the end of the day, what does success even mean? If you look back on your life and smile at least a little, that’s a victory right there.

In the long run, not really. Most people agree that there are hundreds of schools that are as good or better than the eight very different random schools that compete in the Ivy athletic league. What students do in school is infinitely more important than the brand of the school they attend. The Ivy schools are good, of course, but for many students there are much better choices based on location, size and special programs. What you will hear from people who have a different view is that attending an Ivy school is good because you will get to know a lot of rich kids, and those connections are the most valuable benefit of attending. For my taste this is a very stupid reason for obsessing about these schools. If a student is not willing to work to their utmost, all the connections to rich kids will make no difference whatever. After ten years, no one cares where you went to school. They only care about what you have done in your career. An Ivy graduate who is still bragging about their Ivy undergraduate school in their 30s is a pitiful loser.

It certainly doesn't hurt if you can get in and can afford it. If that's the case, then by all means, go for it. Especially if your major is business, economics, journalism, writing/literature, or political science (I'm sure I've missed a few others as well). However, depending on your major, another private or even state school may offer a better experience. I know many successful people and while there are several that went to Harvard, the rest went to MAC schools or state colleges like Rutgers, Illinois, or Ohio State. They may not be CEO's of major corporations, but they have very nice and lucrative careers. Careers that have allowed them to send their kids to $40-60K a year schools. What I've observed is what really seems to matter is what you put into your education, no matter what school you go to. So, before you put yourself into crippling debt just to go to an ivy league school, check into schools that may better fit your academic and career goals. It's a big decision and warrants a little research and an open mind.

My advice: Depends on your capability, where you want to work and what you want to do. Firstly, and most applicable for business schools, you should attend an institute located at or near your desired place of work (state/country) or which has a market reputation to specialize in your desired field or industry of work. Ivy Leagues just happens to fulfill this criteria quite well in the States, but it will not help you massively if you want to be involved in Asian or European markets, where institutes like NUS, NTU, HKU, LBS, Oxford, HEC and INSEAD would have the upper hand in the respective geographies. When it comes to research, more often than not, the Ivy Leagues and other top-tier universities will be able to provide you with the resources to support your research. But again, not a lot of students will have the financial resources to attend these and still could achieve similar if not better results in schools overseas. But for both cases, you need to have the right set of characteristics to be able to utilize these resources and networking opportunities well. So it will be quite stupid and shortsighted to say you, not attending an ivy league, wouldn’t be better off than an individual not as “capable” as you but had the financial resources to get into Ivy Leagues. If you think an Ivy League is right for you and will help you achieve your goals, then go for it. Otherwise, you are just going for it for the sake of it and it would not help you achieve squat.

If you have made yourself capable of running with anyone in your field -- and I don't mean you've made 30 million on your invention -- you might already be an assistant professor at a less heralded but quality state university and be seeking new horizons. Now Imagine a Month Like this Week One Your boss at university sits you down to tell you something. The assistant Provost who oversees your department is getting feelers from bigger universities. They want to know when your contract ends here. They hear you will be an excellent associate Professor. You are not shocked but afraid; this boss has been at times difficult and you cannot see her helping at all. You thank her and say it's all very interesting. You add that you are happy here after two years. She wants to talk about a small raise for next year. Week Two The assistant Provost calls you in. She really has no choice but to ease your transition, she knows your boss is difficult, that you've earned your positive reputation in your field and she wants an ally at a bigger school. She knows what she's doing --the two of you will be networked. She says that two programs will definitely approach you but you don't have to jump at the highest offer. An interview request comes in from the top 60 flagship university a few states away. The Provosts arranges the time off and you have a good trip. The college has Professors you've heard of and more facilities than you imagined. You hold off on accepting the offer though. Week Four You can't believe it. You can taste it. The second offer is from a school near one of your favorite cities and your current Provost explained that they keep Professors for a long time; or loose them to top 20s. The offer is nearly twice the state flagship. Its done. You'll ramp up and learn in the fast lane. The above is a rarity, a lottery win, just doesn't happen. But with a little charisma, personality on a microphone and talent for the scholarship which is not overdone a provost can go to bat for you and want to be in your circle as you progress. If you dream of leading, if you wish to be mentored to leadership you should observe professionals in action and when appropriate emulate them. What Ivy people cannot share with you is that if you show hints of needing them too much it's just not going to work out. They need accomplished go getters with great upside potential who stay lit on fire and see arrival at _______ University as no arrival at all -- just more complete libraries and labs that they can't wait to access. (I personally recall telling Princeton and then Harvard to please show me the libraries available to undergraduates (P) and med students (H). I was told I'd get both a tour and a set of keys to private collections. Someone had called ahead to alert them that I had associate curatotial experience with rare private collections.) Now this is Ivy. Insider Ivy. But the bloke who got hired to the great assistant Professorship will have made his way to be observed and measured by top 20 universities without the old club. A bright light stood up for him --rather with him. That saavy Provost hasn't lost him. The higher he goes the more valuable pieces they may move between them. At the Ivy level the game all new. If you are nobody's great nephew think carefully. This chap may well spend his 30s and 40s rejecting Ivy offers. His network is so easygoing between the Northwestern's, Notre Dames, and a host of top 40s that he is wise to avoid the show. Whether or not he does a final act to temporary replace an eminent at Dartmouth is Cornell while a young gun is found is immaterial to the exercise. He has proven worthy of calling the shots in his long career and Ivy was an option, though a far less independent one. Many of those who find this all an indulgent flight of fancy would opine that of course Ivy matters and that the chump I describe is a weak character. Perhaps so but hundreds upon hundreds of similarly capable assistant Professors within top 120 universities aspire to a top 60–100. To them half his success in a civil work setting and a place they enjoy living defines the win.

This depends totally on what field/major you wish to study and/or what sort of job you wish to work for. If you wanted to become a lawyer, sure, attending an Ivy League School might make a huge difference in how easily you become a top lawyer. However, for engineering, not only are there better engineering schools than the Ivy League universities(MIT, Caltech etc), but also, in most branches of engineering, employers don’t care that much about where you studied from; They would care more about what sort of projects/internships you did and or how much you know. The correlation between the reputation of an engineering school and the availability/quality of projects you work on is not so straightforward; and A LOT depends on how proactive you were in school and/or just general knowledge of your engineering major. [I studied engineering myself and so am mostly knowledgable about these majors] Other than these, even though you didn’t attend any Ivy school during undergrad, you can easily attend one later for grad school if it would help your job prospects. Thus, not attending and Ivy school doesn’t necessarily matter

Depends. Employees look at you different..people do too, like wow. I remember my friends and I have businesses we travel alot , we wear our ivy league stuff. People stare. Funny thing about upenn is people get it mixed up with penn state. I have got business opportunities by just having my Harvard shirt etc on. You still have to know your stuff though. When I talk people go wow cause I explain so well.they go yeah smart dude. Let's do biz. If you want to just make money you dnt need college period. Can just start a realestate investment business and easily make 6 figures in just a few months. How? You can fix and flip two deals In a time frame of a few months at once and make 100 grand easily. Where graduates make 100 grand starting off, however, look at the hours worked and time. dnt need college for realestate, 3 day training and webinars etc. many I know do 2 flips a year make 120 grand a year starting at jan,fixing and sold by March..travel the rest of the year. What is better making 6 figures in 10–12 weeks or 50 weeks lol

I taught at two Ivy League schools, work in a variety of industries and have visited/worked at over 1( universities — so I feel qualified to answer. Matter for what? For a prestige job in banking/finance and grad school — possibly. For inventing a new to do what your industry does — probably not. For living a happy life - depends on your ego (ie if your alma mater affects the way you and your family/friends see you). For getting a tenure track job - kind of (depending on the extent to which you think new ideas come from the individual rather his-her environment). It also depends on the Ivy. Penn and Columbia seem alot less the Dead Poets ideal than Dartmouth or Brown). For making you poorer - undoubtedly. For a job in politics/ government/diplomacy - it hurts more than helps (at least to publicly announce you went to an Ivy League school). What REALLY matters is — WHY are you asking? I mean, your motivation. Your assumption that Ivies are somehow different (if not implicitly better). The implied sense of a different social “face” you get. You need to ask yourself — Why does knowing if/how an Ivy League education “matter” to me? What does that say about me? And the meaning of my life. END

Well it depends on your immediate goals. If your have dreams in working for high finance jobs such as Investment banking analyst in top banks such as Morgan Stanley, Goldman Sachs, in consulting firms such as Mckinsey right out of college etc then an Ivy League/elite college makes sense as these banks and consulting firms only recruit from ''target'' universities. In the UK for example if you want to be a successful lawyer – work in top law firms or become a barrister then you will have to be a graduate from top university – Oxbridge, LSE, UCL etc. Some sectors such as law and finance is highly prestige driven and obsessed, unfortunately. The hanker for pretige universities is truly ridiculous in consulting and finance sector. For example in the UK, a girl who did Language and Classics, ( from Oxbridge) an MA and PhD in the same ( again Oxbridge) now works at Boston Consulting Group. There are plenty of associates and partners in US who has a degrees in philosophy, poli sc etc in ''target'' universities. Now imagine someone who is say a History or Psychology grad with top grades from a State University trying to get an entry into the finance or consulting sector –he/she will be laughed at. Sounds pretty pathetic – but what can you do? In contrast Canada is much more egalitarian – sure you might be respected if you say went to U of T or McGill but all things considered an English/Pol Sc graduate from McGill or U of T and an English.Pol Sc graduate from say Capilano University, or Uni of British Columbia etc will have roughly the same employment prospects – unless they have relevant credentials/work experience a humanities/social science graduate from U of T cannot expect banks and consultancies to welcome him/her with open arms – just because he/she has a degree from U of T. There are quite a few manager level employees at Mckinsey Canada who have graduate from ''non elite'' colleges such as Wilfrid Laurier University. Make that what you will. Outside of legal and financial fields, most employers can care less where you graduated from. For example if you are an engineering graduate from a State University with good grades you stand as good a chance as say a Stanford graduate at a job at Silicon Valley. Tech I have found is the least prestige obsessed field. Even then I would like to conclude, where you did undergrad in does not matter at all in the long run – seriously. Make the best of your time at whatever university you have got into, focus on getting the best grades, you will be set for life.

Five years ago, as a grad student I would have said no it doesn’t matter. I was a student at a state school with a new graduate program and attending conferences with Ivy Leaguers. I felt more than prepared to work and collaborate with the best in my field. Now I think it matters a great deal. I started to explore a career outside of my field, but couldn’t get recruiters or hiring managers to take me seriously. I recently read that ~70% of new hires had a connection to the hiring manager prior to being hired. Ivy League schools have developed large networks of alumni throughout the world in all industries. State schools like mine don’t always have that network. The truth is that your career isn’t decided by what you know, but who you know. This has been one of the biggest disappointments of my adult life.

Yes, I think so. For sure, you will have a better alumni and network, which becomes more valuable as you get older. Also, Ivy League schools have a strong signaling effect, showing that you are probably smart and somewhat know what you are doing. In terms of education quality....you probably get better education compared to very low tier schools but it really depends. Having an excellent research faculty does not directly relate to good teaching. Unless, the costs are exorbitant attending an Ivy league school seems to be a good deal. However, if you care a little less about alumni and network, attending a great state school with a scholarship (or much lower cost) is also a great option. With advent of great MOOCs such as Coursera, EdX, and Udacity, you can supplement whatever the state school lacks in terms of programs. Also, lack of alumni and network can be also compensated by joining certain college groups (fraternity, sorority, honor societies). In terms of signaling, well, thanks God we live in the world of social media, you can show your skills online if your area of focus allows that (e.g. if you are an engineer, you can show what problems you can solve or what stuff you can build).

It seems to me the answers given so far here were interpreting the meaning of "matter" as financially successful. If that's the meaning of "matter", they are right. But is that the purpose of education? If you are a crafts man, art student, music student, and you believe you have the talent, you would want to learn from the best. Where is the best teacher? To say that firms hired the graduate of elite school because of the school name is not fair to the student. We know how many 4.0 students are rejected by Harvard. There is a meaning behind the stellar results of those admitted to Ivy league and graduated. 4.0 GPA  is an accumulation of years of dedicated hard work, aspiration and determination. More over, these school often teaches the mind as in the character of a person. I have met many of those and I found them humble and willing to help and teach others. So please do not belittle those who has achieved what is deservedly a commendable feat and trivialize the value of a good education. Now, what is intelligence? Does it equate education? Were the cave men who know how to start a fire lacking intelligence?

Nowadays the quality of education is somehow similar in most of universities. Ivy league, and more generally super elite schools, will offer a better network through a more competitive selection. In STEM fields, there's another dimension: research. And here, the best ones are generally not Ivy league. To answer the question, I'd say it really depends. If you're in Law school or finance, attending Harvard will open you more doors than any other non-Ivy school. And statistically speaking, you tend to be more intelligent too (selection process). Similarly, if you're in CS, attending Stanford will give you more opportunities given the environment, labs and faculty there. But the coursework is not that different.What you learn, how you master a subject depends on you, your ability and motivation to learn.

Those great, world class universities that element in US motion pictures with all the preppy understudies, tech prodigies, brotherhoods, and billion dollar enrichment reserves. Legitimately Blonde highlighting Reese Witherspoon is my undisputed top choice. What? It's a freakin' great! Also, clearly an absolutely precise portrayal of Harvard Graduate school. All things considered, not in the slightest degree. Harvard and the other Ivy Classes are more famous for their aggressive application forms, scholastic ability and first class graduated class. Yet, so are different colleges! Have you at any point ceased to ask why the Ivy Association universities are considered a great deal more noteworthy and tip top than other world class universities like UC Berkeley, Stanford, MIT, or some other aggressive West Drift school? Without a doubt their scholastics are similarly as trustworthy, isn't that so? Ivy Class offices couldn't be that vastly improved than other tip top colleges. Most likely? Why, at that point, are the Ivies thought about the most elite? What is it an Ivy Class training will really improve the situation you? Also, is it worth the frequently hella costly educational cost charges? Out and out, there are eight Ivy Associations: Harvard, Yale, Darker, Columbia, Cornell, Dartmouth, UPenn and Princeton. Every ha an alternate way to deal with instruction, however every open ways to circumstances inaccessible to understudies at different universities. To start, we should think of some as outstanding Ivy Association graduated class.

This is a question you need to answer for yourself. What it is you seek out of college? If you're meaning “does it matter” in terms of getting a job? Of course not, people all over the world are employed or succesfull, whatever that may mean to you, without an Ivy League education. This is a question that requires introspection on your part. There are very specific reasons I chose to attend an Ivy League college, and it's not just so I can get a job after. I've always wanted to push myself to the absolute limits and be the best I can, not to say this isn't possible at a different college. I am constantly humbled by my terrifyingly intelligent peers, and that pushes me to do better. I wake up and am lectured by professors who are leading the world in their respective field. Everyone here is extremely passionate about their own convictions which gives to classroom discussions that can give you an entirely new perspective on a topic that you've never even considered. I just recently had a class that argued about gender roles in Lysistrata for 2 hours and I'm sure we could've gone longer. It's this type of environment that I wanted to surround myself in to help me grow as a person and become more open minded, so when you ask, “Does it matter?” For me, yes. This is an experience that I wouldn't trade anything else for.

I say it depends on your goals. The only Ivy League school that has my program is Cornell (agriculture and natural resources). I went to Michigan State University and they've been number one in the nation for Nuclear Physics (have one of few rare isotope beam facilities), Supple and Chain Management, and Secondary Education for consecutive years. Having the name of an Ivy League school will get you far and you should aim for it if there program is right for you. But you can still get the same exposure at another university. When I researching abroad with MSU, we stayed at a campus and I met people from University of Michigan, Harvard, and Duke. I presented my research at the same conferences Ivy League students did. I really wanted to go to graduate school at an Ivy League school but I realized not many professors research international food security. Also, if you really want to get in a good school, apply for international schooling as well. I'm going to McGill University in Montreal because I feel it's important for me to get out my comfort zone and study someplace new. Tuition is also more affordable (In state tuition at MSU is more expensive than the international rate at McGill). Do what's best for you!

It depends on your personal goals. Do you want to build a professional network? Do you want to tap into the minds of some of the greatest people? Do you want to challenge your intellect? Do you want to push your boundaries? Do you want to have a degree that's much more valuable, and would give you an upper hand in job hunting? If the answer to most of these questions is a --Yes, then, I think Ivy League degrees matter. Graduating from Harvard, Stanford or University of Pennsylvania maybe a bit of a stretch in terms of grades, and also because they have the lowest acceptance ratio, but they're worth it. After all, getting a degree from one of the Top 5 colleges in the world would have an inherent value attached to it. (Ranking source: Ivy League Colleges Ranking) However, if you're getting into the college just to get a job, or if you're not financially potent to repay the loans, or if you just want to do something of your own, then I think you're stretching yourself for the wrong reasons.   A professional degree helps, but not too much. When you're out in the world, it's all about how practically sound you are, and how quickly you can get grasp of things, and how sincerely you work towards your goals.  That's my 2 cents :)

It depends on how you define “matter”. If you’re looking to be challenged by your education, have the most knowledgeable professors, and go on to an advanced degree in a high-octane field, it does matter. If you just need a BA for job as a postal clerk and education for its own sake doesn’t excite you, chances are you wouldn’t get accepted anyway, so it’s a moot point. There are some jobs where an ivy league degree would be a disadvantage, because you’re over-educated for their needs. Don’t kid yourself that you can get the same education at any school, because it’s never worked that way, and it is getting less so by the minute! I had to go from an “Ivy League West” school to a state university halfway through my undergrad work due to family finances, and the difference in the quality of education and the level of work I was expected to do was shocking. I really wish it weren’t the case, frankly (because the rest of my career was in the state university system, apart from anything else!) but the fact is that in just about every possible respect, attending an Ivy League school does indeed matter.

Kinda, maybe, depending upon your choice of career and your use of the educational platform provided by the specific “Ivy” that you attend. Went to Rice University for my undergrad BArch degree at a time when the program was not nationally known. That said, Rice was then, and still is, a fiercely competitive and rigorous academic platform ; I learned to study, focus, schedule and time-manage my academic process in a way that my high school did not achieve. towards the end of my academic career at Rice, they initiated their now well-known architectural preceptorship program - students were assigned to top-tier architectural practices for a year between the fourth and fifth years… I came to Philly to work at a prominent design firm, returned after I graduated to continue as a “conventional employee”. Spent my time visiting classmates in NY, Boston, Washington… and added a “brand name” firm to my resume before graduating. That noted, my fellow classmates and I all felt that we needed an “Ivy’ on our resumes…. So, I applied to four “Ivy”s, selected UPenn because of the program, the scholarship and the ability to maintain my teaching gig at Drexel and my modest “moonlight practice”. Initially, the UPenn master’s degrees carried substantive weight on the East Coast for “resume glamour”, but - over time, as Rice’s general reputation and their specific reputation with the School of Architecture have leaked out of the state of Texas, the scales have balanced… and, of course, any academic setting will, over time, reduce in impact based on career successes…

There was quite a thoughtful article on this recently on the BBC. The included a very helpful graphic showing the different earning potential between colleges of different relative prestige.  How much difference does going to a top US university make? But, like the old saying goes - there are lies, damned lies and statistics. A group of researchers pulled together some fairly compelling data that students who are admitted to the Ivy Leagues do very well in their careers whether or not they actually attend an Ivy League school. In other words, Ivy Leagues and similar schools are very good at identifying very able candidates - the sort of candidates who tend to do very well regardless where they go to university. Estimating the Effects of College Characteristics over the Career Using Administrative Earnings Data

Not one bit… Now, graduating from one doesn’t hurt. (Seriously, though, there is a small, but important problem with students starting a school they cannot afford or manage to complete. More pronounced at other schools, but still, 3 years of Harvard, unless you’re going off to be Zuckerburg or Gates is not worth a whole lot on its own.) This has been pretty well answered, but it would be great if there were a few other top-tier school sports leagues that could get the same name recognition and dampen the “Ivy League” as the defacto “top tier” US college shorthand. CIT, MIT, CMU, JHU, Chicago, and two others should form the Genius League or Nobel League or something, then we could have two top leagues. the NESCAC should have called themselves the “Elite Tweed League” or the “Reading the Illiad by Fireside League” or something… Branding is everything, even in 1930…

Yes, an Ivy League education will matter in the job market. If you’re working in New England in banking, finance, & investments; law; consultancies, or theatre it can open some doors. You”lol encounter lots of people like you. If you’re outside that region or those fields, you’ll probably encounter some resistance unless and until you can show mastery in your field through practical, unglamorous work delivered on Time. You see, there’s a strong anti-elitist sentiment especially when you get off the coasts into areas derided as the “Rust Belt” or “Flyover States.” People can quickly assume that an Ivy Leaguer is entitled, arrogant, spoiled, incapable of self-sufficient operation, and has lived in a “bubble.” You’ll have to prove that you’re not the stereotype to get and sustain a job. Fitting into the local social and political systems may be tough, especially if you don’t have family or religious connections.

Does going to an Ivy league school really make that much of a difference? It depends a lot on whether you avail yourself of the extraordinary networking opportunities that the Ivies encourage. The networking is helpful to find jobs on graduation as well as for social, business and academic connections throughout life. The institutional camaraderie and pride of the Ivy experience crosses school boundaries. Even though students and graduates of the seven Ivies feel honor bound to disparage one another constantly, they actually believe that they are collectively among the elect. Yalies don’t worry a lot about hiring Harvard or Princeton graduates even though they may tease them unmercifully. The thoroughly rebuttable presumption is that they’re getting quality. That makes it easier to get through the door in the first place. Once you’re through the door, of course, the rest is up to you. To some substantially more limited extent, an Ivy diploma invests graduates with a modest amount of cachet that may help them compete with other qualified people. In most circumstances there is a slight hiring bias in favor of Ivy graduates who are also socially and technically skilled. Life is tough, and any advantage helps. Technical and social skills are necessary conditions for success, but in a world populated by emotionally driven social animals they are far from sufficient conditions. In that context, effective networking is a principal differentiator. The Ivies teach networking.

Name dropping your school. I got an internship because “notre dame” was on my resume. The hiring manager actually told me the reason she picked out my resume was because the manager was a huge fan of ND football. The job I have now I got hired only because “Harvard” is on my resume. The CEO at this fairly small company wanted to say she had someone from Harvard working for her. From what I have heard from my coworkers, the only thing they talked about during my hiring process was “Harvard”. I was straight out of college and right now I am in grad school in the evenings so I didn't even have the knowledge from it, yet. Just the status. It makes you stand out from other resumes and hiring managers notice when someone from “Yale” or “Princeton” applied.

Here are 5 thoughts on this question Tons of people are successful whether or not they went to an Ivy League school.2. Is it the school or the student. Many people from ivy leagues schools are successful because they needed to be smart and driven to get into an Ivy League school. Thus those traits not the school itself make them successful later on. 3. Many that go to an Ivy League forget what it took them to get into an Ivy League school. Drive and intelligence etc etc. Thus they dot’t do so well afterwards. 4. An Ivy League school can be tough on someones confidence. When u go to an ivy u are suddenly not so comparatively brilliant. For many this is very bad for confidence and not great for success. 5. In business, drive intelligence and personal skills all matter. Again on average ivy leaguers will tend to do well. But many of the best leaders and business people and everything weren’t ivy leaguers.

You are unlikely to ever suffer because you have an Ivy League education, unless said education comes at the price of not majoring in something that is important for your post-graduation plans. For example, most (all?) Ivies do not offer an accounting major. If you plan to be an accountant after you graduate, that might be an obstacle, because employers who want to hire accountants expect their accounting hires to have learned about accounting. However, most jobs don’t require a specific major, and having a degree from an Ivy confers a lot of prestige. And some firms only recruit from Ivies and peer schools. So, to sum it all up, it doesn’t usually matter, in the very strong sense that relatively few careers are barred to you if you don’t graduate from an Ivy. But those careers do exist (investment banking, management consulting), and going to an Ivy does generally give you a leg up. So apply if you have a realistic shot, but don’t think you can’t have a decent career without that particular credential.

It may help getting that first job. But, I have worked in a lot of environments where most of the people went to ivy league universities. Some people with low self esteem may want to base their credibility on which school they attended, but the reality is that no one cares in that environment. I would want the best people to work on a project with me and that encompasses a lot of factors including their work product and personality. I really don’t care what school they went to as much as whether the work they produce makes me look good, But, if they were equally bright, wouldn’t you rather work with the one that was enthusiastic and personable, and shares their views in a positive way? If people want to work with you, in many environments that determines your success. A lot of people are very successful who did not attend Ivy league law schools BTW. In law school, people don’t think of Ivy League as much as Top 14 or T14.

Depends on what do you want out of your education It looks good on your resume, helps you to find a good job, it impresses people who didn't go to an Ivy League.  You get more resources, in terms of the alumni network, better educational resources, famous professor, better than average quality courses.  Having the Ivy League name on your resume is a great stepping stone for those fresh out of school. But... Millions of people who attend a non-Ivy school (or Stanford, MIT, etc.) are as smart and as capable as those Ivy League kids.  So, attending one doesn't do much in the long run.   Asking this question in a different way - Can you become as successful as those Ivy League kids without attending one? What do you think?

I went to Berkeley. As a result, through a professorial connection, I ended up spending seven formative and fascinating years in Papua New Guinea. At an Ivy League school, you’re unlikely to get an experience like that. I also, more recently, took a course on innovation from HBX, the Harvard Business School Extension. It was taught by Clayton Christensen. He said that HBS degrees were so expensive that their graduates could only afford to work for a big corporations, and there they spent most of their time crunching spreadsheets. So yes: it matters—if you want to have a wealthy, narrow life. If you don’t, go elsewhere.

It matters that you get a good education, it matters that you meet peers who bring a diverse set of backgrounds and world experiences to share with you, it matters that your are given opportunities for research, travel, and jobs after you graduate, it matters that you will be able to get all of this without incurring significant student debt (Financial Aid | Harvard College).  Going to an Ivy League school such as Harvard is definitely not the only place where you can achieve some of these goals... but it one of the places that you are likely to achieve all of them.  There are many paths in life, an Ivy League education is just one of them.

It depends on the career.  For many, if not most, careers it is probably overrated - even if you restrict yourself to careers that require a college degree.  For a handful of careers it matters. Want to teach high school?  Overrated.Want to work on Wall Street?  It matters.Preparing to be CEO of your small to mid-size family business?  Overrated.Want to be one of those consultants that flies all over the world telling businesses how to improve?  It matters.Want to practice family law in a small town?  Overrated.Want to be a high-priced lawyer in New York or Washington, D.C.?  It matters.

An Ivy League education can be an assist in securing the first job in your major. Of course, that means that the companies are hiring in your major course of study. Ivy League schools are in the first tier of recruited schools so on-campus interviews offer students an opportunity if they have a high Grade Point Average, and have majored in the areas of hiring interest for interviewing companies. However, don’t be misled by the on-campus interviews. The recruiters are furnished with a list of openings at the entry level the management is interested in filling. The recruiters then try to select a few for on-site interviews by the people doing the actual hiring. Sometimes these on-site interviews are a bust if you don’t exactly line up to the company’s expectations or if the recruiter has been given the incorrect requirements of the company. I had one of the latter type on-site interviews. I traveled by train to a city southeast of Pittsburgh. My escort was a young man only recently graduated himself. We toured the manufacturing facility and then went to the office area that was essentially deserted. In fact, I saw no one except the young man and I asked pointedly with all the empty desks why they would be hiring a fresh college graduate. He said he didn’t think they really were hiring and didn’t understand my invitation for an on-site interview. In fact, he had me fill out an expense form and took it to accounting who wrote a check for me before the end of the interview. As far as I know the company went out of business within months. I think the on-campus interviewer must have been a service organization that was paid well in advance and not told the company’s position.

IMHO it depends on who you are. If you are someone who can really leverage social and business connection an Ivy League school or its equivalent can be a huge advantage. If you are extremely talented and can leverage the input/participation of a mentor there may be value there. If you are a loner or extremely introverted it may not be an advantage. If you do not have the work habits to do well, you may get a worse education than you would at a community college. I’ve seen students at Ivy’s and equivalents, (Yale, Princeton, Harvard, Stanford, U of Chicago) that did NOTHING with their education but I’ve also seen others for whom it made a huge difference. It isn’t just a matter of the status of the school but finding the right fit. I have a friend that went to Havard, hated it and went to Pomona College which worked out for him.

IMHO, the obsession students (and parents) have for the Ivy League schools is over done. Yes, the student accepted at Yale is more likely to graduate that a student who attends their state university, and, on average, they are going to earn 12% more. However, when selection bias is factored in, most of that advantage fades away. Making a success out of college today is a very tricky business. Choosing a marketable major and having a solid financial plan that minimizes student debt is going to get you a long way. Notes Who Needs Harvard? I suggest you read Frank Bruni’s, Where You Go Is Not Who You’ll Be. Will Attending a More Selective School Guarantee Future Success? I hate to say this, but, in my experience, “luck” plays a greater role in navigating this labyrinth than we would like to believe. For example, if you are going to college in the Age of COVID-19, all bets are off.

Most of the truly elite private colleges will meet your complete financial needs (based upon what the College perceives your financial need to be). Each college in the USA is Mandated to provide a Net Price Calculator so that you the future applicant can plan on net cost (after any college provided financial aid).   Here are my rules of thumb: Find the best colleges for You with the best fit for You.  That includes all the majors you may wish to pursue, in a region and setting that is good for You, with an undergraduate community that is good for You, etcUse the net price calculators to determine which of those colleges is cost-effective for you.Do NOT borrow more than what is provided by the Federal Direct Loan program, which is $27,000 maximum over four years (about 60% of that will have subsidized interest, which means No interest accumulates until 6 months after graduation)Graduate within four yearsFollow that advice and you may be at Williams, or Princeton, or MIT or SUNY Stony Brook, or CUNY, etc.     The best fit for You, that is cost effective and under no circumstances borrow more than $27,000 total over the four years and only from the Federal Direct Loan program. Easy.

Ivies are definitely worth it, but so are other elite schools. Elite degrees of all kinds serve as a signalling mechanism for recruiters (whether in HR, grad school admissions, etc). Whether you go to MIT, Duke, CalTech, or Harvard, your degree is a proxy for the following traits: intelligence, work ethic, class / background, and more. More importantly, you may meet the children of incredibly powerful people in college. Many of your peers will go on to become CEOs, heads of state, etc. Social circles are incredibly important if you want to be successful; the myth of the self made (wo)man is just that-- a myth.
