The network you gain from elite schools is powerful. Thanks for A2A.

It doesn’t matter. One of the world’s top topologists, prof. Todorcevic, attended some subpar elementary and secondary schools, so much subpar that he was getting Cs and Ds in math for the first two years of high school. According to his recollection, he had no idea what he was supposed to do, what math was all about etc. He began to get sense about it only at the end of his high school education at which point he started to lecture other students including his teacher. And at the university, he started to regularly correct his future mentor in his own field, a sound name in mathematics. The professor wanted his master thesis to become his PhD dissertation due to its quality, but he refused. And when he defended his PhD dissertation, the faculty could not provide 3 examiners who could understand what the thesis was all about (they had to invite two professors from England to serve as examiners). Schools are overrated, talent is everything.

The only factor an Ivy League provides that other colleges do not is the premium network Of individuals. College is not really about grades and degrees. A degree is simply social proof that you've had access to specific information and study. The contacts you will have from attending an Ivy League are going to be extremely more impactfull and powerful Versus a lower ranking college. Honestly, in the real world, it's not about the degree but about who you know, what you know and the quality of your inner network. You are the average of the 5 people closest to you.

You’ve asked the wrong person. I don’t see any true benefits other than you might be in class with a future president or Supreme court justice. Since that’s never been on my bucket list, I never gave that any thought at all. Specially when tuition and living expenses in one of those schools is reported to be much higher than paid locally or at no more than a neighboring state. Harvard Business School blew it for the whole conference when they said to consider only the bottom line. Real Life says to consider the life of the business as equally if not more important. (There wouldn’t be any Century old businesses if that weren’t true.)

You certainly don't have to go to an Ivy League school to be a success. You have to make a success of yourself. And if you are a good, hard working, inquisitive student, you'll probably learn a lot in a less rich setting. But in an Ivy League school you'll be in constant contact with the world's best and most creative intellectuals. So, if you can handle the work load, it may be a big help to you. On a purely practical note; my experience has been that having that MIT degree allowed me to walk right in to every job I ever wanted. I hope I myself may have had something to do with it.

If you care about making certain connections it can be helpful, but attending an Ivy League school is not the most important thing by a long shot. Let’s say you go to Harvard law and graduate. I’m sure that will open up some doors for you. However, it’s what you do with those doors that matters most. Someone who went to a smaller school can certainly do as well and better if he is hard working and competent. What you contribute matters more than any school you attended.

no ; it does because its a wonderful education; does it make a difference in how much knowledge you get or your success in life? not at all ; zero; its a great thing if you do it; but just as good if you don’t; no the myth of the magic ivy league is 100 per cent bs; and it doesn’t matter at all; education at a top public college is identical to any ivy; its what you do with it; relax; also what they don’t tell you; is its really hard to get into a top school as a freshman but as a transfer 3.6 - 3.7 out of a good school will get you into almost any ivy; its much easier as a transfer? no it doesn’t matter at all all the changes you and your friends are putting yourselves through is pure bs; ( i can tell you as a former extra honors student who bought into all this )its pure bs

hell yes! it’s primarily due to the connections we make with other students and alums (well, along with the prestige factor.) and after we’re done? yet another generation hires a/o marries one another-or a friend of a friend from a different ivy or prep school. silver lining, though? the only reason I have my private school, Ivy League privilege is thanks to my father. he nearly flunked out of a no name college since he worked full time as a busboy to pay tuition.

Regardless if a student can afford to go to an Ivy League school, it's more important to go to a school that is the right fit for a student and one where they can thrive academically and personally. There is a large emphasis placed on the ranking of a school, but people overlook if a campus is the correct fit for them very often. It's definitely useful that you're thinking about where you want to go to college already, but you should look into all possible options that fit certain criteria that are important to you, such as class and campus size, location, etc.

It’s a pretty broad question since it really depends on what your final goal is. But assuming your priority is getting a prestigious job with solid starting salary, going to Ivy League school matters to some extent. No matter what your major is, you will be more likely to get a quality lectures, research/internships opportunities, and most of all powerful connections. Those factors shape you into a better candidate for jobs, and industry knows that too. fyi, having studied at the state school, Ive always admired a high student-to-faulty ratio at liberal arts colleges.

One difference I’ve found is in the recruiters that come to college. Top companies (Goldman, Google, etc) have limited resources and send recruiters to only their best prospects, so if you don’t go to a top school, you probably won’t even be interning or interviewing with these companies. Also, when a company gets a pile of a few hundred resumes of inexperienced young people, one quick filter is the school, since you don’t have much job experience. So an Ivy education is always better. It’s hard to imagine a scenario where it is worse. Whether it’s worth the price is a different question.

Of course it really matters to the individual who worked hard or maybe had the right connections or both to get into an elite, comepetitive school. In our society it is a traditionally recognized sign of achievement. But so is getting into Stanford or Annapolis or West Point. Does getting into a top school open every door afterwards - no, not at all. It is just one step up a steep hill. Getting into a top law school or med school or graduate program is even tougher - and not everyone who does went to an Ivy school. So in educational society we are surrounded by these obstacles and pyramids and labels - this is the way the world works - at least in the USA. In other words, getting in is just a start - long ways to go depending on your desired career path.

The Ivy League is an athletic league of eight colleges/universities in the northeastern US. All except Cornell were founded during colonial times. Apparently, there were some “maybes” when the league was formed, including William and Mary, Rutgers, West Point, and Annapolis, but nothing came of that. (These are all public institutions, so that was probably part of the rationale.) The Ivy League is not taking new members, so nothing about upgrading is going to happen. But reviewing the list of the “Little Ivies” (https://www.nescac.com/about/members ) I’d imagine that Tufts might be first in line if such a hypothetical expansion event occurred.

It depends, on many factors. First of all, what area of study do you wish to pursue? Penn, where I did my undergrad, has a strong business program but a weak math program (for ex). At the end of the day, what’s going to define your experience and future are how you spend your four years and the opportunities you choose to pursue. Don’t feel like you have to go Ivy League if another option makes more sense. There are plenty of people who don’t take advantage of opportunities at schools like Penn who emerge afterward without direction and preparation for the real world.

Worth what? Future earnings?Eventual happiness?Interesting learning opportunities?Good professors? On that last: I went to Cornell, and my wife had better teachers at our local community college than I did in my major, which was applied physics.  My profs couldn't have cared less about us. You might also get some interesting insights from the answers here: What do Ivy Leaguers think of non-Ivy Leaguers?

Yes, it really does. I’m a professor at a very well regarded Ivy right now, but my first job out of Harvard was with a world-renowned consulting firm to which I never applied—they headhunted me, and all they cared about was Harvard and during the interview that’s really all they wanted to talk about. My fellow consultants from other Ivies told the same story, while virtually everyone else working there had gone through a tiresome and nerve-wracking application process.

The Ivies are all great schools, but there are lots of other great places.  The Ivies really don't have much in common.  Remember that it is an athletic league!  Brown isn't at all like Columbia.   Don't obsess about the Ivies.  Focus on finding a school that is a good fit for you.  I think it is a worthwhile investment to go to a good school.  However, look for a school that matches your career interests, first and foremost.  Most schools discount freshmen year grades.  So a 3.0 isn't the end of the world.  Concentrate on taking the most challenging courses you can.  Don't take an Honors or A.P. class, if you are sure you can't get at least a B.  A C never looks good.

What the others said. It’s good stuff. Well motivated students with strong backgrounds will do well wherever they go to school. Selecting on the basis of cost/benefit, proximity, or campus environment often over rules heading to the northeast for an elite education at any one of eight very different colleges. The more I look at the Ivy’s, most of which I’ve at least visited on campus for one reason or another, the more different each of them looks from the others. If, for instance, Cornell, for it’s agriculture, or Dartmouth for its combination of top academics with winter sports, has something unique to offer you as an applicant, then you should certainly apply. If you’re simply wishing to hang a label on yourself, be careful. And ALWAYS apply to a rich variety of colleges where you would be happy including at least one or two where your application will for sure be accepted. It’s just foolish to do anything else.
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Anthony Graham Clark

response.answer_text: That is a complicated question to answer, but I will try. I graduated from Brown University. I did not enjoy it, despite getting high marks. I do not feel I learned more than at any other university. In truth, university is what you make of it. Those who are more pro-active with getting to work with other students, knowing professors, etc. will do better. Yes, for some firms such as Wall Street firms, etc. they care. Yet, there are people who did not go to Ivy League’s who are still successful. Find out what you want to do with your life, and others will help you network. Message me at bj80klunder@outlook[dot]com if you want mentorship.

Speaking from the Ivy League of my country, it helps you find awesome people with varying degrees of out of the box thinking. I am a firm believer that it is the students that make the school. You can learn the same skill in any decent school, but it is the gathering of minds that make it special. Missed on an Ivy League? Too expensive? Cannot stand places full of 'stuffy, elitist' people? Go around and start to find yourself a decent community. Travel. Spend your time where debates are being held, intellectual curiosity is regarded. Read books, and discuss what you have read even only to a bedraggled homemate. Just keep your mind starving.

Attending a top tier school will definitely provide you with a better platform. It definitely opens more doors. Say for example: I was going through some internship positions at Amazon and this is what I saw:  However, in most cases it is your talent that matters more than the university you graduate from.

I'm from Canada, we don't have Ivy league schools but some are considered to be at that level. I went to McGill university, a school that is considered an Ivy league equivalent. I grew up in a low income family so I didn't have those special connections from the get go as opposed to rich kids. The school did not help me get a job though connections ( everyone was over competitive and still are today) I got a job on my own through hard work and perseverance. They also did not help me get an internship I had to get that on my own too after 2 years of searching for one the rich kids got it through parents. After I graduated nobody really cared were I graduated from. If I had to do it again I would have went to an easier school and get much better grades and party which I didn't do there because I had low grades and worried about failing all the time.

I don’t quite remember where I heard this, but I believe it sums things up nicely: “A shithead at an Ivy League is still a shit head.” The drive, grit, and will power of a student tends to do much more for them than a prestigious degree. There may be a tendency for these types of people to be concentrated in the Ivies, but that’s it. Being at an one of these institutions will give you many resources and a competitive environment that can push one to grow, but it is by no means a magic machine that turns of all their students into Isaac Newtons by the time they graduate.

TL;DR With some exceptions, it generally matters most for high finance, management consulting, and politics. It plays a decent role in law and academia. Does attending an Ivy League school really matter? For what? Attending an Ivy League school matters if you want to tell people you went to an Ivy League school (but then again, the people who care about you because of that are probably not the people you want to be friends with). But assuming your definition of matter does not center on perceived prestige, and instead, on career success defined by income, it’s a bit more complicated
College is what you make it. It is like the question, "What do they call the person who finishes last in his medical school class. The answer is "Doctor".

Think of car racing. Does having a Ferrari guarantee a win? Or maybe it's a combination of the drivers, the mechanics, the engineers, the brake men, the tire men, the managers? Sure, you MIGHT have a bit of a “halo" around you, but in the final analysis, it's what you did with what you have that counts. Have you ever heard of Al Roker? Now there's a graduate from the mid-size SUNY Oswego who made it big! And he's far from being the only success story from a State School! As you make your way through college applications, give your State University System a chance!

Well, that really depends on the career you're pursuing and the type of job you want? If you're interested in Finance, Financial Accounting, Law or Medicine, I would say, “Yes, without a doubt!” But if you're going for education or some other miscellaneous career then any college of education will be just fine, but if you're planning on working for a big financial firm or bank, Ivy League is a great way to get your foot in the door and a lot quicker than other applicants.

From my experience, it depends on your field of study. There are plenty of public universities who have better program reputations than Ivy league schools. For example, I went to Brown University as a Computer Science major which is a ivy league school with a mediocre Computer Science program. However, my sister was a Computer Science major at The University of Maryland College Park which is a public university but has a wayyyyy more reputable and respected Computer Science program compared to my school. There are many rich and successful Alumni out of the Computer Science program at UMD including Sergey Brin. How many from my school? Nowhere near as many as University of Maryland. So it all depends.

You better believe it. The same is true of good non-ivy league schools like Stanford or the University of Chicago. Your college degree follows you the rest of your life, so go to a top school if you can. Otherwise do your best wherever you are and that will be enough. At the same time remember that emotional intelligence is a much better predictor of success in life than grades or the school you graduated from.

Being founded before the revolutionary war generally helps. As does playing the other such schools in sports. It's not some RPG where the school can “level up” to being an ivy league school. It's not a group of the best schools in the country, it's an athletic conference.

I would say yes. In my country, not so many people manage to get Ivy League education but those who manage secure jobs that pay handsomely, and those who have ventured into business are real entrepreneurs. Ivy League education also exposes them to great minds and networking opportunities that help them disrupt the modern world. Here is a story of three Ivy League graduates from Africa who are doing great things in Africa: Ivy league graduates leave high flying careers in the US to help Africa move its money - Kenya Witness. I believe it’s a great opportunity for you and/or your children.

I have never seen this happen. The 8 Ivy League schools were formed as a sports league in the 1950’s because the schools had similar values, standards and philosophies. The 8 Ivies are: Harvard, Princeton, Yale, Dartmouth, Cornell, University of Pennsylvania, Columbia and Brown University.

“Does an Ivy League school education really matter in the job market?” The general answer is “no”. First and foremost, do not pay attention to fancy names. Employers care more about qualifications than fancy names. Look at your specific major and find the programs that are well ranked for that major (US News is a good starting point). Even then, don’t think that you absolutely have to go to the very top program. You will generally find that you can get a similarly good education at the #1 school and the #20 school, and the #20 school may be cheaper and easier to get into. Another thing you can look at is which schools are most sought after by employers for your field. There are lists published for certain fields on different websites. Interestingly, those statistics often do not correlate with the rankings of the programs.

It really only seems to matter to those that went to Ivy League schools. We should always fight that middle class bourgeois mentality that can creep into our lives. Do your best to 'Keep it real' but it's not always easy with the many different influences impacting our complex lives today.

In the short term, it matters. But, in the long term it does not. Ultimately, the top two advantages to going to a top tier school are (1) the network of people you will develop and (2) the opportunities available to you immediately upon graduation. However, ultimately, future success is completely dependent on work ethic - work hard and the world can be yours, rest on your laurels and suffer the consequences. There are tons of people out there that went to no-name colleges, or never finished college, and ended up extraordinarily successful.

Whether or not it matters depends on your goal. Do you want a fast track to the opportunity to connect with powerful people? The Ivy League is more likely to give you that. However, note that what generally matters much more than the name on your diploma is the set of useful skills you bring to your professional field.

A2A.Is an Ivy League college really better? Better than what? Better is a comparison adjective. For example, if you are asking if an Ivy League college is better than MIT or Stanford, the answer would be no; however, for UC Merced, the answer would be yes. To answer this question by doing a cost benefit analysis, I would need the names of all the schools involved and their respective costs of attendance to see if the benefits outweigh any extra costs of attending an Ivy League school.

Yes. The Trouble With Harvard is an excellent article demonstrating why going to an ivy league university is a wise thing to do.

Their professors are no better than the professors at many quality liberal arts colleges. You might be able to make good connections for future jobs by attending an Ivy League School. They DO NOT offer “merit money” for being smart; so, that might be a consideration. In essence, there is no right or wrong answer to your question.

According to some people, it really matters. Of course, it depends who answers your question and what is their intent. If you can attend one of these schools if that is your wish, do so. If not, have no regrets and make the most of whatever opportunities come your way.

response.answer_text: I went to Brown University in Rhode Island and it did not really help me. I can tell you that befriending powerful people (directors, managers, doctors, pharmacists) is the key to success in this country. Also, study the right thing, such as STEM majors.

In my experience, ivy leaguers like to hire other ivy leaguers. Other employers are much less impressed and more likely to rely on your experience. An ivy league school, combined with a big ego, is often seen as a negative. I personally don’t hire people with big egos.
